Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Bridging Electronic Focus and Aberration Control for Scanning Laser Microscopes from Lab to Commercial Readiness
Award.AbstractNarration:
A grant has been awarded to Dr. David Dickensheets at Montana State University to develop a new instrument for electronic focus and aberration control in biological microscopy, with particular application to microscopy of thick living tissues or intact animals. A critical tool for studying living systems in their natural state, high-resolution microscopy of living and intact tissues remains a tremendous challenge. This project addresses a major technological barrier for in vivo microscopy: controlling the focus and managing aberrations when imaging through thick, unprepared specimens.
Most current instruments for vital microscopy rely on mechanically fixing the specimen in some manner and then translating the microscope objective lens in or out to adjust focus. A system has been developed based on a deformable MEMS mirror (MEMS is an acronym for micro-electromechanical systems) that adjusts the location of the beam focus in the sample while maintaining the objective lens in a fixed position. There is no mechanical translation of any lenses or of the sample, and therefore no vibration. Precise control of the mirror shape eliminates spherical aberration at every depth. Fast response time allows focus stepping or scanning, and when synchronized with lateral beam scanning allows sectioning of 3D samples along any oblique plane or even along convoluted surfaces such as a cell membrane. No competing technology offers the precision, speed and potential low cost afforded by MEMS deformable mirror technology. The underlying technology of electronic focus and aberration control using a MEMS deformable mirror has been demonstrated in our laboratory. The aim in this project is to bridge the gap between our first prototype demonstration and an instrument ready for commercialization and broad distribution. When fully developed, this technology will turn any laser scanning confocal or two-photon/multi-photon microscope into an electronically controlled 3D imaging instrument, capable of x-y, x-z or arbitrary trajectory scanning. With the proposed instrument and future software development, many sophisticated image acquisition schemes would become possible including multi-plane imaging, enhanced depth of focus at high NA, and image feature tracking and stabilization.
The scope of potential use for this new technology is extremely broad. The first module in development is for scanning laser microscopes, but future applications include fast, aberration-free electronic focus control for wide-field white light and fluorescence microscopes and miniaturized in-vivo microscopes designed for laparoscope, endoscope or catheter platforms that presently have extremely limited ability to adjust focus in situ. Advances made with the deformable mirrors will be of interest for applications in astronomy, photography and optical data storage. In addition to its scientific impact the project embraces integration of research and education, training one female engineering Ph.D. student and providing research experience for several undergraduate engineering students, who will participate directly in cross-disciplinary activities with biology researchers as they vet the technology. This project will also participate in an established summer internship program for students and faculty from tribal colleges in Montana.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are developing a new instrument for fast, precise electronic focusing in biological microscopy, with particular application to laser scanning microscopy of thick living tissues and animals. With the laser scanning microscope, a focused beam of light is rapidly scanned in an x-y raster pattern to form a two-dimensional image. When we add fast control over the location of focus, we give the instrument true 3D imaging capability. This will enable real-time imaging of “surfaces” that are more biologically interesting than an x-y plane; for instance a microscopist could choose to image an undulating layer of cells in the sample, following the natural contours of the biological structure. Or, with appropriate electronic control, fast focus tracking could allow microscopy of moving tissue like an embryo’s beating heart, addressing questions in developmental biology that are not possible with current technology.

This IDBR project is a “bridging” project, with the overarching goal of translating a first generation demonstration instrument toward commercial readiness, that is, to a point where serious commercial development can occur to make this technology widely available to the biological research community. To bridge that gap we had to make improvements to the underlying micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) mirror technology and the electrical control interface, and we worked with a partner company to transfer the technology from the university to the private sector. A further goal of the project is development of human resources through education of undergraduate and graduate students in engineering, and in particular to give those students exposure to and experience with challenging problems in the biological sciences.

The innovation that allows fast and precise control of the beam focus is a millimeter-dimension mirror whose surface curvature may be controlled electronically. The mirror serves as a variable-focus lens that can change instrument focus in much less than a millisecond. Three variations of the mirror were investigated, all of which were made of a thin, metal-coated polymer membrane. Two of the mirrors are actuated electrostatically, and one employed a combination of electrostatic and pneumatic actuation. Annular actuation zones allow precise control over the surface shape so that the mirror can compensate spherical aberration while changing the location of focus. The dominant mechanism controlling speed of actuation is air damping, which we investigated in some detail in order to properly place channels to facilitate air flow beneath the membrane. Through this effort we have demonstrated mirrors with the largest stroke-bandwidth product so far reported, a metric that captures both the range of focus the mirror can achieve and the speed at which it can operate. This combination of large focusing range, high speed that allows focus adjustment to keep up with the lateral beam scanning, and precise control over spherical aberration distinguishes these mirrors as the best currently available for dynamic focusing for scanning laser microscopy.

During the project we worked with a partner company who licensed and improved the mirror fabrication process. Ultimately a new company, Revibro Optics, was created specifically to develop and sell active focusing elements and advanced imaging solutions that leverage the technology. This is a significant outcome, with the hope that commercialization will be an effective way to increase the reach of this instrument development effort to make it available to researchers worldwide.
